awd_titl_txt: Spin Injection and Manipulation in Graphene-based Spintronics Devices
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims at developing an integrated experimental and educational framework for understanding of dynamical spin pumping, spin injection, and generation of pure spin currents in graphene-based spintronics devices. A series of experimental and theoretical research activities have been strategized in collaboration with the Graphene Research Centre at the National University of Singapore. The goal of the proposed research is to develop nanoscale devices for information processing where a complete control of the magnetic state is possible without relying on charge currents. Within emerging spintronics technologies, the generation and control of pure spin currents is becoming of paramount relevance. The unique property of graphene offers the advantage of pure spin current devices as preeminent candidate for the next generation of information processing and storage hardware. The proposed research will be integrated with a series of educational and training activities, including training of graduate students at the interface of fundamental and applied physics, and gain experience from international collaboration. The PIs are committed to involving underrepresented groups in the research activities at all levels.

The project proposes a series of experimental and theoretical research activities for the understanding of injection and control of pure spin currents in graphene-based spintronic devices that uses dynamical spin pumping and the spin-Hall effect (SHE). The goal is to develop nanoscale devices for information processing where a complete control of the magnetic state is possible without the direct intervention of net charge currents. The proposed devices will make use of the unique properties of graphene to allow generation and manipulation of pure spin currents for controlling the magnetic state of the device that not possible with spin transfer torque devices based on non-gateable elements. The specific objectives of the project are to: a) understand dynamical spin pumping from a ferromagnet (FM) into single-layer and multi-layer graphene (Gr) under different structural conditions exfoliated, chemical vapor deposition grown, and hydrogenated graphene) and for different interfacial configurations (FM/Gr and FM/MgO/Gr); b) understand the SHE in single-layer and multi-layer graphene under different structural conditions and study its behavior as a function of the gate voltage; and, c) develop graphene-based gateable pure spin current valves that uses both dynamical spin pumping and SHE to allow for an efficient control of magnetic state of the devices and explore their potential applications for next generationlow-power high-speed MRAM, information processing and storage devices.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual merit

Experiment:

We have performed FMR experiments on different FM/Gr interfaces designed to systematically identify and eliminate damping enhancement arising from processes other than spin pumping. In particular, a substantial enhancement of the Gilbert damping observed in Py/Gr strips when the graphene layer protrudes a few micrometers away from the edges of a narrow Py strip is univocally associated to spin pumping at the quasi-one-dimensional interface between the Py edge and graphene, which shows lower spin-mixing conductance values (6.89?1018 m?2) than in extended films but still comparable to those obtained in Py/Pt interfaces (e.g., ~1-4?1019 m-2). These results have been reported in an article published in Applied Physics Letters.

We have reported detailed charge transport studies individual redox-active molecules (based on ferrocene) over a wide range of temperatures and applied potentials. The results show the temperature dependence of the current to vary strongly as a function of the gate voltage. These results have been reported in three articles in Nature Communications, Scientific Reports and Dalton Transactions.

We have advanced the understanding of tunnel current though molecular tunnel junctions by looking at the behavior of the tunnel current as a function of bias potential in junctions with highly asymmetric molecules. An article reporting these results has been published in Nature Nanotechnology.

We have investigated tunnel junctions based on compound molecules in view at exploring potential candidates for the realization of the spin-current Seebeck effect. In particular, we have studied a molecular tunnel junction based on compound molecule with a ferrocene (Fc) head group connected to a conjugated backbone via a (CH2)n tether. This system acts as a molecular double quantum dot leading to reciprocal electrical gating as the molecule charges as a function of bias. A manuscript reporting these results is currently at the last stage of review by Nature Nanotechnology, with very positive comments and currently addressing some minor remarks by the reviewers. 

In addition, we have also reported a surprisingly moderate and positive spin Hall angle (0.004) in Uranium, which is just merely comparable to those of several transition metals. These results have been reported in an article published in Applied Physics Letters.

Theory:

On the theory side, we have developed a microscopic formulation that allows for the computation of spin currents injected into metals by resonant ferromagnets. The formulation is based on single-particle Green’s functions and allows for the inclusion of disorder and spin-orbit interactions in the metal portion. The results have been published in Physical Review B.

 

Broader impacts

Four graduate, two undergraduate and two high-school students have benefited from the knowledge acquired during the first year of the project. Three experimental graduate students have been trained in microscopy and microfabrication techniques, as well as low temperature and high sensitivity transport spectroscopic characterization techniques. Two have already graduated (fall 2014 and Spring 2016), and the third will graduate  before the conclusion of the project (Summer 2017). Two high-school students (started in Fall 2014 and Fall 2016) have been involved in sub-projects related to the main goal of this award. In addition, two undergraduate students have started to collaborate with del Barco’s group in activities related to this project. One of them has been supported by REU Supplemental Awards associated to this project during the years 2 and 3 of the project. The theory student has been trained on state-of-the-art analytical and numerical techniques for computing electronic transport properties Students have also benefited from active interdisciplinary collaborations with other groups in USA and abroad and have gained experience from attendance to local, national and international conferences where they have presented their research results. He is graduating in Spring 2017. An addition, two graduate students benefited from two 2-month research visits to the state-of-the-art facilities of the Graphene Research Centre of the National University of Singapore during the summers of 2015 and 2016, supported from international travel supplements to this award. In addition, the PIs have been actively involved with outreach activities in different fronts to involve the youngest students in the research covered under this project. Under-represented groups of population in science are the main targets of our approach.
